context.text: This case is here on direct appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out at some length in the written opinion of the Court filed with the clerk this morning, we hold that a state law authorizing unionization and an agency shop arrangement for public sector employees in this case, Detroit school teachers is not constitutionally invalid for collective bargaining purposes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But we further hold that under the First and Fourteenth Amendments, no such employee maybe required to give financial support to the furtherance of any idealogical cause with which he disagrees.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals of Michigan is vacated and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this Court's opinion.

context.speaker: Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
context.text: We submit that when it is possible for an employee to work 10 or 15 or even more years and not receive any pension at all, it is difficult to conceive that the pension as simply being a form of deferred compensation.

context.speaker: Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
context.text: Moreover, pension plans fill needs of the employer that other aspects of the employment relationship do not and the District Court based its decision we feel on this ground.

context.speaker: Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
context.text: Employers naturally want a stable and experienced workforce and the promise of a pension after years of service encourages employees to stay with the company throughout their career and this serves the need of the employer to develop that stable workforce.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Ryan, let me go back a minute to the provisions of C1, which Mr. Justice Stewart and I were asking you about yesterday afternoon and that provision after we talk about restore without loss of seniority that shall be entitled to participate in insurance or other benefits offered by the employer person to establish rules.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Wouldn't it be a perfectly orthodox statutory construction to say that that portion of the statute grants all it is to be granted in the way of participation in insurance or other benefits?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In other words, they cover what they wanted to give the ex-serviceman in the way of insurance or other benefits in that portion and therefore, you cannot go back and read seniority as covering the grant of pension plan.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We conclude that pensions are an incident of seniority because they are in the nature of a reward for length of service.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 76-357, Linmark Associates against the Town of Willingboro will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The case involves a challenge to the constitutionality of an ordinance, prohibiting the posting of real estate for sale and sold signs.

Linmark Associates, Inc. v. Township of.speaker: Justice Marshall

Linmark Associates, Inc. v. Township of.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 02, 1977

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: By an opinion filed today with the clerk, we hold that the ordinance violates the First Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We conclude that the law cannot be sustained on the ground that it restricts only one method of communication because the alternative it leaves open are unsatisfactory and because the township was concerned with the message of the signs rather than with the media.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We also conclude that the township's interest in promoting stable, integrated housing does not justify the ordinance since the law is not needed to achieve that objective and since the First Amendment disables the township from achieving that objective by restricting the free flow of truthful commercial information.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 75-657, Local Union 34-89 of the Steelworkers against Usery will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit held that the provision of the constitution of the United Steelworkers of America limiting eligibility for local union office to members of the local who had attended at least one half of the local's regular meetings for three years previous to the election of officers did not violate §401(e) Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act which provides that every union member in good standing shall be eligible to be a candidate in the whole office subject however to reasonable qualifications.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree with the Court of Appeals in reserved.

Local 3489, United Steelworkers of Ameri.speaker: Justice Brennan

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree with the Court of Appeals in reserved.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that where a meeting attendance requirement, as was the case of this one, resulted an exclusion of 96 and a half percent of petition of local's members from candidacy for office.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The requirement cannot be considered a reasonable qualification consistent with Title 4 goal and free and democratic union elections since the requirement having that result, restricts the free choice of the membership and selecting its leaders.

context.text: Whalen against Roe is a case involving the constitutionality of the New York law requiring that prescriptions for certain potentially dangerous drugs be prepared and triplicate on a special form which identifies the name and address of the patient.
